avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger above the treeline is moderate, below that altitude danger is low. 
Freshly generated snowdrift accumulations from fresh snow and brisk NW winds on Tuesday can be triggered by 1 person in some places, releases often medium-sized. The foehn-induced snow from the weekend can mostly be triggered as a slab avalanche only by large additional loading, esp. on east-facing slopes and wind-loaded gullies. 
There is still latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, most releases medium-sized, occasionally larger.

avalancheProblems.comment: in gullies, steep bowls, behind discontinuities, near to and distant from ridges, triggerable in transitions from shallow to deep snow
on steep grass-covered slopes, possible at any time of day or night,

snowpackStructure.comment: Fresh snowdrifts above the treeline lie deposited atop soft snow layers. The old snowpack surface is highly irregular due to wind impact. Above 2300 m both blanketed surface hoar and faceted crystals near crusts can serve as weak layers, esp. on W/N/E facing slopes. At intermediate altitudes the snowpack has repeatedly been made thoroughly moist and compact.

tendency.comment: Gradually receding snowdrift problem, but due to warmth loose-snow avalanches (small, nataurally triggered) and glide-snow avalanches can become more frequent.

weatherForecast.comment: Clouds will disperse, visibility in the afternoon will be adequate, isolated minor snow showers are possible. Winds will be light-to-moderate from the northwest (up to 30 km/hr). At 2000 m: -3 degrees; at 3000 m: -9 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger is moderate above 2000 m, below that altitude danger is low.
Snowdrift accumulations triggerable by 1 person in some danger zones, releases mostly small. Danger of falling outweighs that of snow masses. Danger zones increase with ascending altitude, occur in steep gullies, bowls on NW/N/SE facing slopes. Drifts are not easily recognized, due to diffuse light, and can be covered. 
There is still latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, medium sized releases are possible on high-altitude slopes.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Pay close heed to fresh snowdrifts

avalancheProblems.comment: in gullies, steep bowls, behind discontinuities, near to and distant from ridges
possible at any time of day or night

snowpackStructure.comment: The fresh snow from Tuesday (5-10 cm) is wind-compressed in places. The old snowpack surface is highly irregular due to wind impact. At intermediate altitudes the snowpack has become moist repeated times and is very compact. Below 1400 m there is hardly any snow on the ground.

tendency.comment: Gradually receding snowdrift problem, but due to warmth loose-snow avalanches (small, nataurally triggered) and glide-snow avalanches can become more frequent.

weatherForecast.comment: Clouds will disperse, visibility in the afternoon will be adequate, isolated minor snow showers are possible. Winds will be light-to-moderate from the northwest (up to 30 km/hr). At 2000 m: -3 degrees; at 3000 m: -9 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger is low. 
There is still latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, most releases medium-sized, occasionally larger.
Small snowdrift accumulations can be triggered by 1 person in a few places. Danger of falling outweighs that of snow masses.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Pay close heed to gliding snow

avalancheProblems.comment: on steep grass-covered slopes, possible at any time of day or night,

snowpackStructure.comment: Some fresh snow/snowdrifts atop a stable surface. At intermediate altitudes the snowpack has become moist repeated times and is very compact. Below 1400 m there is hardly any snow on the ground.

tendency.comment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

weatherForecast.comment: Clouds often dominate, a bit of minor snowfall is possible. Visibility improving in the afternoon, sunshine is possible. The NW winds will be light. At 2000 m: -3 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger above 2300 m is CONSIDERABLE (3), below that altitude danger is moderate.
Freshly generated snowdrift accumulations from fresh snow and brisk NW winds on Tuesday can be triggered in some danger zones by 1 person and grow to medium size. Danger zones increase with ascending altitude, occur esp. behind discontinuities and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The foehn-induced snow from the weekend can mostly be triggered as a slab avalanche only by large additional loading, esp. on east-facing slopes and wind-loaded gullies. 
Above 2300 m there are near-surface weak layers in the snowpack, triggerable in some places by 1 person, large-sized releases possible, esp. on very steep shady slopes.
There is continuing latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, usually medium-sized, occasionally larger.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Heed: fresh snowdrifts and persistent weak layer at high altitudes

avalancheProblems.comment: behind discontinuities, near to and distant from ridges, in gullies, steep bowls
on steep grass-covered slopes, possible at any time of day or night

snowpackStructure.comment: Due to southerly foehn wind on the weekend, fresh snowdrift accumulations have been generated, deposited atop a soft surface above 2000 m. Due to stormy NW winds, more fresh snowdrift accumulations will be generated, deposited atop soft layers. The surface shows marked effects of wind impact, is highly irregular. Above 2300 m near-surface layers have faceted crystals near crusts, also near covered surface hoar, which can serve as weak layers, esp. on W/N/E facing slopes. At intermediate altitudes the snowpack has become moist repeated times and is very compact.

tendency.comment: Gradually receding snowdrift problem, but due to warmth loose-snow avalanches (small, nataurally triggered) and glide-snow avalanches can become more frequent.

weatherForecast.comment: Clouds will disperse, visibility in the afternoon will be adequate, isolated minor snow showers are possible. Winds will be light-to-moderate from the northwest (up to 30 km/hr). At 2000 m: -3 degrees; at 3000 m: -9 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger above 2200 m is moderate, below that altitude danger is low.
Fresh snowdrift accumulations can be triggered in some danger zones by 1 person, releases usually small.  Danger of falling outweighs that of snow masses. Danger zones increase with ascending altitude, occur esp. behind discontinuities and in gullies and bowls on NW/N/SE facing slopes. Drifts are not easy to recognize due to diffuse light, they can be covered as well.
There is continuing latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, usually medium-sized, occasionally larger.

avalancheProblems.comment: in gullies, steep bowls, behind discontinuities, near to and distant from ridges, in transitions from shallow to deep snow

snowpackStructure.comment: Snowdrifts lie atop soft layers on NW/SE facing slopes. The snowpack is highly irregular due to heavy wind impact. At intermediate altitudes the snowpack has become moist repeated times and is very compact. Below 1400 m there is hardly any snow on the ground.

weatherForecast.comment: Scattered clouds will permit sunshine, visibility is good. The NW winds will be light-to-moderate. At 2000 m: -5 to 0 degrees.
